Unless baseline risk adjustments were inadequate, there are likely 92 time trends in IFR, which would also help reconcile the disparate estimates noted in the two 93 meta-analyses cited above. 94 Another possibility is severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virulence 95 could differ across geographic locations because some local strains have higher or lower 96 virulence than others. Previous reports have argued that evolution of attenuated strains is 97 expected for RNA viruses and that "determination of naturally circulating attenuated CoV-2 variants is an urgent matter." Patient 121 outcomes were then aggregated into positive ("Mild") outcomes or negative ("Severe") 122 outcomes (detailed in Supplemental Figure 1 ). Briefly, "Mild" outcomes included: Outpatient, 123 Asymptomatic, Mild, Home/Isolated/Quarantined, and Not Hospitalized. "Severe" outcomes 124 included: Hospitalized (including severe, moderate, and stable) and Deceased (Death). Patient 125 outcomes that were unclear or empty were not included in our analyses. 146 We collected a total of 155,958 viral genomes along with clinical metadata. The metadata 147 included numerous entries whereby the severity of the condition could not readily be discerned.

For example, "recovering", "recovered and released", and "mild symptoms inpatient for 149 observation" were found in the raw data and were not included. Viral sequences were 157 obtained from the six major geographical regions in GISAID between January and October 2020 158 (Supplemental Figure S2 ).

SARS-CoV-2 variants associated with "Severe" / "Mild" outcome categories 160 The overwhelming majority of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 genomes assessed were rare, with 161 only 12 common variants with at least a 5% minor allele frequency ( Figure 1C ). Two of these 162 common variants (C26735T and C28311T) were associated with "Severe" or "Mild" outcomes, 163 as measured by having an odds ratio of greater than 2 or ≤0.5, respectively. We also observed 84 164 of 157 rare variant associations with "Severe" or "Mild" outcomes. Collectively, 17 variants 165 were associated with "Severe" classification with at least an odds ratio of 2, while we found 67 166 associations with "Mild" classification (OR≤0.5). The variants associated with outcomes were 167 distributed across the genome, including the strongest "Severe" association within the C-terminal 168 end of the spike protein ( Figure 1B ). We 177 hypothesized that viral genomic variants in the virus could also contribute to severity 178 classification. When accounting for the region of collection, we observed an increased c-statistic 179 to 0.817 (0.817-0.818). Previous observations show that regions tend to be dominated by 180 individual viral clades, and we found that adding clade to an age/gender/region model resulted in 181 moderate improvement of accuracy (81% vs. 86%, respectively) with a nearly identical AUC of outcomes. In addition to the improvement in c-statistic, we compared the accuracy of our 188 predictions, which started at 81% for the age-only model and improved to 86% and 88% for each 189 additional step in the model building before finally reaching a maximum at 91% accuracy for the 190 age/gender/region/variant model.

Classifications based solely on age or on age and gender resulted in insignificant odds ratios in 192 our models. Both models had the same odds ratio (4.4), confidence interval (2.8-6.0), and p-193 value (0.072). However, the other three models all had significant odds ratios with p-values less 194 than 0.0001. Discussion: 203 We demonstrate that including genomic viral variants can substantially improve classification of 204 COVID-19 patient outcomes as compared with models using only age and region. Moreover, in 205 our models, we observe that some individual variants are particularly important with substantial 206 associations with severity, and that collectively these variants are not rare.
Associations between viral genomic variants and patient outcomes are not unexpected.

Consistent with known patterns in the evolution of virulence in RNA viruses (9, 10, 23), we 209 would expect many common strains have differing association with patient severity by this point 210 in the pandemic by chance alone and even as sampling is more likely to occur with severe 211 outcomes, variants correlated with mild outcomes are still being identified. Therefore, by providing a molecular risk 292 factor for more severe outcomes, these findings could help prioritize limited treatment supplies 293 to those at greatest risk, particularly as therapeutic interventions for infectious disease often need 294 to be given early in the disease course (e.g., empiric antivirals for influenza).

There are limitations with our analyses. First, the SARS-CoV-2 genomes uploaded to GISAID 296 are not necessarily representative of all circulating genomes, which can introduce a selection or 297 sampling bias into our analyses based on region, patient severity, or other unmeasured factors. In 298 Supplemental Figure S2 we show the sampling patterns over time by our patient severity 299 categorization. We sought to mitigate these limitations by eliminating the categories that had 300 ambiguous severity (e.g., "live" or "recovered"), and adjusting the associations for known 301 confounders. In addition, we do not seek to make causal claims about any specific viral genomic 302 variant. In aggregate these variants are predictive of outcome and the candidates we identify can 303 be further studied using molecular and other methods.
In summary, we have demonstrated that some SARS-CoV-2 genomic variants are strong 305 predictors of COVID-19 disease severity, and these variants appear to be commonly circulating.

This study provides a rationale for prioritizing control efforts for cases and populations 307 manifesting with unusually high severity, consistent with symptom-based criteria for testing used 308 by the CDC. Longitudinal monitoring of genomic variants within a novel pathogen such as 309 SARS-CoV-2 will be important for understanding drivers and effects of its evolution and 310 ultimately, its spread or control.
